https://www.fool.com/investing/2021/01/2.Article Title: Where Will Alibaba Be in 1 Year?
Relevant Text: The past year has been a volatile one for Alibaba (NYSE:BABA), China's largest e-commerce and cloud platform company.
However, a series of regulatory challenges abruptly ended Alibaba's rally at the end of the year.

Chinese regulators suspended the long-awaited IPO of Alibaba's fintech affiliate Ant Group, fined Alibaba for Alibaba unapproved takeover of InTime Retail, then launched an antitrust probe into Alibaba e-commerce business.

Meanwhile, the "disappearance" of Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma, rumors of China's plans to nationalize Alibaba and Ant, delisting threats in the U.S., and the Pentagon's desire to add Alibaba and Tencent (OTC:TCEHY) to an investment blacklist over Alibaba and Tencent (OTC:TCEHY) alleged ties to the Chinese military all cast a dark cloud over the stock.

However, Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma recently reappeared in public, and the Treasury Department blocked the Pentagon's push against Tencent and Alibaba shortly before President Joe Biden was inaugurated.
Alibaba's stock rebounded after those developments, but Alibaba's still underperformed many of Alibaba peers.
Alibaba's stock has risen about 17% over the past 12 months, while Baidu (NASDAQ:BIDU) and Tencent have rallied 87% and 71%, respectively.
Will Alibaba catch up to Alibaba "BAT" peers this year?
Or will Alibaba continue to struggle as regulators kneecap Alibaba core businesses and allow rivals like JD.com
to gain ground?Is Alibaba's business still fundamentally strong?Alibaba controlled 56% of China's e-commerce market last year, according to eMarketer.
Alibaba's main marketplaces, Taobao and Tmall, are primarily paid listing platforms.
Alibaba doesn't take on any inventories, but Alibaba fulfills orders through Alibaba logistics subsidiary Cainiao.
JD.com takes on inventories and fulfills Alibaba orders with Alibaba first-party logistics network.
Pinduoduo offers paid listings like Alibaba, but Pinduoduo encourages shoppers to team up on bulk purchases.

Alibaba generates most of Alibaba revenue and all of Alibaba profits from Alibaba core commerce business, which includes all Alibaba online marketplaces, brick-and-mortar stores, and logistics services.

Alibaba subsidizes the growth of Alibaba three other unprofitable businesses -- Alibaba Cloud, Alibaba digital media and entertainment unit, and Alibaba innovation initiatives -- with the profits from Alibaba core commerce business.

This cycle enables Alibaba to expand Alibaba ecosystem with other services, including streaming media, cloud services, video games, and even a search engine, to widen Alibaba moat against Tencent, Baidu, and other tech giants.
Baidu's also enabled Alibaba to generate robust revenue and net income growth over the past five years:Growth (YOY) 2017 2018 2019 2020 6M 2021
33%Analysts expect Alibaba's growth to accelerate in the second half of the year, and for Alibaba revenue and earnings to rise 48% and 35%, respectively, for the full year.
However, investors shouldn't place too much faith in those forecasts, which might not fully reflect the impact of China's recent antitrust moves against Alibaba's e-commerce business.

aheadThe growth of Alibaba's online marketplaces was already decelerating prior to the antitrust probe, and Alibaba had grown increasingly dependent on lower-margin businesses -- including brick-and-mortar stores, wholesale channels, cross-border marketplaces, and Cainiao -- to boost Alibaba core commerce revenue.
That's why the adjusted EBITA margin of Alibaba's core commerce business dropped to 35% in the second quarter, down from 38% in both the first quarter and the prior-year quarter.
That decline might seem minor, but that downward trend could continue and impair Alibaba's ability to support Alibaba other unprofitable businesses.
To make matters worse, China's antitrust regulators reportedly plan to prevent Alibaba from locking merchants into exclusive deals.
JD, Pinduoduo, and several merchants have called these deals -- which bar Alibaba's sellers from cross-listing their products on other platforms -- anticompetitive.
If those new rules are passed, Alibaba's merchants could list Alibaba's merchants products on other platforms and cause unprecedented challenges for Taobao and Tmall.
The road aheadAlibaba currently trades at just 20 times forward earnings, compared to forward P/E ratios of 29 and 21 for Tencent and Baidu, respectively.
Alibaba's stock certainly looks cheap, but Alibaba arguably faces more regulatory headwinds than Tencent and Baidu.

I believe Alibaba's valuation will limit Alibaba downside potential this year, but I also believe Baidu will underperform Tencent, Baidu, and other Chinese tech stocks as China's antitrust regulators find new ways to rein in Baidu dominant e-commerce and cloud businesses.

Relevant Text: Moody's assigns A1 to Alibaba's proposed senior notes; outlook stableGlobal Credit Research - 03
Feb 2021Hong Kong, February 03, 2021 -- Moody's's Investors Service has assigned an A1 senior unsecured rating to the proposed USD notes to be issued by Alibaba Group Holding Limited.
Alibaba will use the proceeds for general corporate purposes and for eligible projects in connection with Alibaba sustainability notes.

RATINGS RATIONALE"Alibaba's A1 issuer rating reflects RATINGS RATIONALE"Alibaba integrated and diversified e-commerce platforms, which provide sustainable cost advantages that allow Alibaba to generate solid profit margins and maintain strong credit quality with a solid net cash position," says Choi.

Alibaba's well-established brand name and dominance in China's (A1 stable) fast-growing e-commerce market; Alibaba track record of monetization through fees from online marketing, services and subscriptions; and transaction-based commissions," adds Choi.
The rating incorporates risks related to Alibaba's aspiration to continue expanding Alibaba business scope within and outside China.

As Alibaba expands Alibaba businesses, Moody expects Moody currently high profit margins to be diluted because of the consolidation of strategic business initiatives such as Ele.me, Lazada and Cainiao Network.

However, strategic business initiatives such as Ele.me, Lazada and Cainiao Network should also help Alibaba grow Alibaba scale and expand Alibaba service offerings, and in turn strengthen Alibaba cash flow.

While a recent antitrust investigation by the State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) is credit negative and could limit Alibaba's revenue and earnings growth, Alibaba has a track record of working with regulators to make operational changes without materially hurting Alibaba solid business profile.

In view of Alibaba ongoing investment requirement and heightened regulatory risks, Moody expects Alibaba to maintain a strong balance sheet with net cash position over the next one to two years, along with a prudent approach to investments and acquisitions.
The rating also takes into account potential contingent liabilities associated with Ant Group Co., Ltd, in which Alibaba holds a 33% stake.
Alibaba's proposed senior unsecured notes will improve Alibaba debt maturity profile and expand Alibaba capacity to accommodate any funding needs over the next one to two years.
Alibaba's proposed senior unsecured notes will have limited impact on Alibaba's debt leverage, as earnings growth in the coming one to two years should offset the increase in debt.
Moody expects Alibaba's revenue to grow around 20% per annum in the next one to two years from the RMB644.2 billion reported for the 12 months ended December 2020.

Moody also expects Moody to maintain steady EBITDA margins of 20%-25%.As such, Moody expects Alibaba's adjusted debt/EBITDA will stay around 1.0x-1.2x in the next one to two years, which is appropriate for Moody A1 ratings.
Alibaba's liquidity is excellent.
As of 31 December 2020, Alibaba held RMB456 billion in cash and cash-like resources.

Together with estimated annual operating cash flow of RMB180 billion-RMB210 billion, Alibaba's internal cash flow is more than sufficient to cover Alibaba reported short-term debt of RMB15.0 billion, capital spending and investment needs.
In terms of social factors, Alibaba is exposed to heightened scrutiny by regulators with respect to perceived anticompetitive behavior, in turn raising legal, regulatory and reputational risks.
legal, regulatory and reputational risks could impede Alibaba's business growth.
Alibaba also faces moderate data privacy and security risks, as Alibaba generates and processes a large volume of personal, transaction, demographic and behavioral data.

https://www.fool.com/investing/2021/02/0.Article Title: Why I'll Never Own Alibaba Stock
Relevant Text: I once considered Alibaba (NYSE:BABA) an undervalued growth stock.
Alibaba (NYSE:BABA)
an undervalued growth stock still trades at just 21 times forward earnings, and analysts expect Alibaba (NYSE:BABA)
But after carefully reviewing Alibaba again, I believe I'll never buy this seemingly attractive Chinese tech stock, for three simple reasons.1.
Alibaba growing dependence on lower-margin businessesAlibaba resembles an inverted version of Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN).

Whereas Amazon subsidizes the growth of Amazon lower-margin retail segment with Amazon higher-margin cloud business, Alibaba subsidizes the growth of Alibaba unprofitable businesses (including Alibaba cloud division) with Alibaba higher-margin "core commerce" revenue.

Therefore, Alibaba's future earnings growth relies heavily on Alibaba core commerce segment, which includes Alibaba online marketplaces, cross-border marketplaces, brick-and-mortar stores, and Cainiao logistics unit.
Alibaba's core commerce business is still growing at a healthy clip.
Alibaba's core commerce business core commerce revenue rose 35% in fiscal 2020, which ended last March, and accounted for 86% of Alibaba's core commerce business top line.
Endless regulatory challengesMeanwhile, a seemingly endless barrage of regulatory challenges in the U.S. and China could make it even tougher for Alibaba to keep growing.
Alibaba's secondary listing in Hong Kong in late 2019 indicates Alibaba days on the NYSE could be numbered.
In China, government regulators clearly want to rein in Alibaba.
In 2019, China sent officials to work at dozens of companies, including Alibaba, to oversee companies, including Alibaba operations.

Last year, the Communist Party's Central Committee tightened that grip by requiring all companies to hire a certain number of registered members of the CCP.That tension finally boiled over last year when China brought China hammer down on Alibaba.

China derailed the long-awaited IPO of China fintech affiliate Ant Group, fined Alibaba over an unapproved acquisition, and launched a full antitrust probe into Alibaba e-commerce operations.government regulators reportedly want Alibaba to end Alibaba exclusive deals with merchants and throttle Alibaba promotional pricing strategies, which could make Alibaba tougher for Alibaba core profit engine to keep running.
Alibaba would also leave Alibaba more exposed to competition from JD.com
(NASDAQ:PDD) -- which both previously accused Alibaba of anticompetitive strategies.3. Ethical considerationsBack in 2017
, China declared that China would rely on Alibaba for the development of smart cities, Tencent (OTC:TCEHY) for digital healthcare, and Baidu (NASDAQ:BIDU) for driverless cars.
The term "smart cities" might seem vague, but The term "smart cities's collectively referring to Alibaba's cloud services and facial recognition technologies.
That's already troubling, but Alibaba recently demonstrated how Alibaba technologies could be used to identify the faces of Uighurs and other ethnic minorities across China.
Alibaba claims the feature can be embedded into websites to monitor users for terrorism, pornography, and other "red flags.

"China's human rights record is already dismal, and "China's human rights record's currently accused of imprisoning and sterilizing Uighurs in reeducation camps, so Alibaba's disturbing claims spark far too many ethical concerns.
Alibaba could also make Alibaba an easy target for sanctions if the Biden administration maintains the Trump administration's tougher stance against Chinese tech companies.
As a result, I'm avoiding Alibaba for the same ethical reasons I recently sold Tencent: I'm simply not interested in owning a piece of China's mass surveillance system.
The key takeawayI understand why Alibaba still looks like an appealing stock buy for many investors, and Alibaba could certainly climb higher in the future.

Relevant Text: Alibaba (NYSE:BABA) recently posted fiscal third-quarter numbers that easily beat analysts' expectations.

Alibaba (NYSE:BABA) adjusted earnings increased 21% year over year to $3.38 per ADS -- which also surpassed expectations by $0.13.The company revealed that $0.13.The company cloud business, which grew 50% year over year to 16.1 billion yuan ($2.5 billion) during the quarter, was finally profitable after bleeding red ink for over a decade.

That revelation might instantly spark comparisons between Alibaba Cloud and Amazon Web Services (AWS), the profitable cloud infrastructure platform that supports the U.S. e-commerce giant's online marketplace.

But such comparisons would be flawed, since Alibaba Cloud is not nearly as profitable as AWS.Decoding Alibaba's definition of "profitability"At first glance, Alibaba's cloud computing results don't seem to make any sense.
But on an adjusted EBITA (earnings before interest, taxes, and amortization) basis, Alibaba Cloud squeezed out a slim "profit" of 24 million yuan ($3.7 million).

taxes, and amortization) also excludes the unit's stock-based compensation expenses, which rose 41% to 2.1 billion yuan ($316.2 million).Therefore, it's unlikely that Alibaba Cloud will turn profitable on a GAAP basis anytime soon.

CFO Maggie Wu noted that Alibaba Cloud ongoing infrastructure investments, along with Alibaba Cloud massive scale, enabled Alibaba Cloud to turn profitable on an adjusted EBITA basis, but CFO Maggie Wu didn't address the unit's rising stock-based compensation expense or widening operating losses.
Don't confuse Alibaba Cloud with AWSAlibaba is often compared to Amazon, but the two tech giants operate completely different business

Meanwhile, Alibaba generates all of Alibaba profits from Alibaba higher-margin "core commerce" business, which supports the expansion of Alibaba unprofitable cloud, digital media, and innovation initiatives

That's why the core commerce segment's adjusted EBITA margin fell seven percentage points to 34% during the latest quarter, which drove company-wide adjusted EBITA margin down almost four points to 28%.Alibaba probably won't be able to strengthen 28%.Alibaba core commerce margins near term, especially as China's antitrust regulators probe 28%.Alibaba e-commerce marketplaces, so 28%.Alibaba needs Alibaba Cloud to pick up the slack.
That effort might partly offset the ongoing erosion of Alibaba Cloud core commerce profitability, but investors shouldn't expect Alibaba Cloud to become an AWS-like profit engine anytime soon.

The bottom lineThe growth of Alibaba's cloud business is encouraging, but investors should remember three things: Alibaba revenue growth will likely decelerate in the future; Alibaba stock-based compensation is rising; and it's only profitable if you exclude those and other expenses.

MercadoLibre (NASDAQ:MELI) and Alibaba (NYSE:BABA) are two of the world's largest e-commerce companies.
Alibaba launched the same year and has become China's top e-commerce and cloud services company.
Alibaba made Alibaba market debut at $68 in 2014, and shares trade at over $240 as of this writing.
Meanwhile, Alibaba stock advanced less than 20% during the same period as ongoing regulatory concerns kept many investors away.

The differences between MercadoLibre and AlibabaMercadoLibre splits MercadoLibre operation into two main segments: Alibaba commerce business, which earns commissions and shipping fees from sellers, and Alibaba fintech business, which includes Alibaba payment service Mercado Pago and Alibaba credit system Mercado Credito.
Alibaba generated 64% of Alibaba revenue from Alibaba commerce business in the first nine months of 2020 with the rest coming from Alibaba fintech services.

Alibaba splits Alibaba business into four main segments: the core commerce unit, which covers Alibaba online and brick-and-mortar stores; Alibaba Cloud, Alibaba cloud infrastructure platform; the digital media and entertainment unit, which includes Alibaba streaming media and online gaming businesses; and the innovation initiatives segment, which houses Alibaba other non-core businesses.

Though there are four reporting segments, Alibaba generated 87% of Alibaba revenue and the entirety of Alibaba profits from Alibaba core commerce business in the first nine months of fiscal 2021 (which ends March 31).
Alibaba is consistently profitable, but Alibaba continually subsidizes the growth of Alibaba unprofitable ventures with Alibaba core commerce segment.

Turning to Mercado Pago's TPV (total payment volume) counterpart in the Chinese market, Alibaba grew revenue 34% year over year to 529.9 billion yuan ($81.2 billion) in the first nine months of fiscal 2021.

Core commerce revenue rose 34%, but Core commerce revenue margins are contracting as Alibaba relies more on lower-margin businesses (including Core commerce revenue brick-and-mortar stores, cross-border marketplace, direct sales, and logistics unit) to drive Core commerce revenue top-line growth.
But looking ahead, Alibaba could face mounting pressure to narrow the losses at Alibaba three unprofitable businesses as Alibaba core commerce profitability declines.
Alibaba also faces an ongoing antitrust probe in China, which could force Alibaba to eliminate Alibaba exclusive deals with merchants and aggressive pricing strategies for new users.

Those headwinds, along with intense domestic competition and tighter auditing requirements for Chinese stocks in the U.S., likely held Alibaba stock back as other e-commerce stocks soared over the past year.
Profits will continue rising too, but Alibaba stock still looks pricey at 570 times forward earnings and 15 times 2021 sales, even though it may be cheaper relative to other high-growth tech stocks.
Alibaba is not far behind with consensus estimates for 51% and 31% revenue growth in fiscal 2021 and 2022, respectively.

Those are impressive numbers for a stock that trades at just 20 times forward earnings and less than five times sales, but Alibaba regulatory hurdles could still cause Alibaba to miss those rosy expectations and result in other challenges for the company long term.
MercadoLibre also won't suffer as much as Alibaba if trade tensions escalate between the U.S. and China again.
That's why I personally own MercadoLibre rather than Alibaba, and investors are better off buying the former over the latter right now.

In the next few quarters, I think Pinduoduo will report more active buyers than Alibaba.
Alibaba revenue grew 44% during the quarter when China first imposed statewide lockdowns, demonstrating that Alibaba can handle external shocks.
Pinduoduo boasts a fast-growing platform almost as large as Taobao and Tmall, the marketplaces that Alibaba owns.
Yet Pinduoduo's annual revenue is just a fraction of Alibaba's $14 billion in China-based e-commerce revenue for the same period.

Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) and Alibaba (NYSE:BABA) are the world's two biggest e-commerce companies and, in many ways, the world's two biggest e-commerce companies are mirror images of one another.
Alibaba:
The best of growth and valueAlibaba shares were rocked in recent months by rumors that founder Jack Ma was "missing" and after Chinese officials announced an antitrust investigation into Amazon.

Those events underscore some of the risks facing Chinese stocks like Alibaba, but the stock's recovery once founder Jack Ma made a public appearance is a reminder that those risks are often exaggerated.
Like Amazon, Alibaba has put up strong growth during the pandemic even as China rebounded much faster than the U.S. from the crisis.

Alibaba's revenue jumped 37% in Alibaba most recent quarter to $33.9 billion and Alibaba finished the year with 779 million active annual consumers, showing the value of operating in a massive market like China.
Because Alibaba core business is an e-commerce marketplace, Alibaba is also highly profitable, collecting commissions on sales on Alibaba marketplaces like TMall and Taobao.
Over the last year, Alibaba passed $1 trillion in gross merchandise volume (GMV), making Alibaba the biggest online marketplace by GMV in the world.
In its most recent quarter, adjusted EBITDA increased 22% to $10.5 billion, giving Alibaba a 31% adjusted EBITDA margin.

Alibaba's other businesses like cloud and logistics saw revenue growth of 50% or better in its most recent quarter, and Alibaba is also continually expanding through partnerships with businesses like Farfetch and Dufry, leveraging other companies' assets and increasing Alibaba competitive advantages.
Alibaba is an attractive partner for almost any brand looking to do business in China.
Alibaba's base in China also sets Alibaba's base in China up for strong growth.

Amazon trades at a price-to-earnings valuation of 75, while Alibaba is valued at just 26, making Amazon nearly three times as cheap as Amazon.
Considering the significant valuation gap between the two stocks, Alibaba is the better buy today.

While both of these stocks look poised to outperform the S&P 500 over the coming years based on both of these stocks competitive advantages and growth momentum, Alibaba is the better value of the two.
Alibaba lower price tag gives investors assurance that even if growth stocks fall -- a distinct possibility in the economic reopening -- Alibaba shares will remain solid.
